choices.answer: someone speaking to only one person.
someone telling it like it is.
the exact words a character or person has said, in writing.
someone talking to an audience.
keep the teacher happy.
make it clear who is speaking and what they are saying.
to tell us how the words are being spoken.
to make our work look nice

questions.question: Which of these is correctly punctuated?

choices.answer: "I'm glad I now know how to use speech marks," said Jay.
"I'm glad I now know how to use speech marks, said Jay.
"I'm glad I now know how to use speech marks, said Jay."
I'm glad I now know how to use speech marks, said Jay.

questions.question: What is wrong with this sentence?: The baby cried, "give me more sweets!"

choices.answer: It's too short.
It doesn't need the comma.
Missing full stop at the end
Missing capital letter at the start of speech

questions.question: Which one of these sentences is correctly punctuated?

choices.answer: "Go away" she shouted.
Milly asked, "Why are you so sad"
He replied, "Because it's not fair."
"Ouch" he screamed in shock.

questions.question: "I'll be right back," said the doctor, "as soon as I eat lunch."

choices.answer: Correctly punctuated
Incorrectly punctuated

questions.question: What punctuation is missing from this sentence?: "NO!" shouted Bethany "It's not my fault."
When writing direct speech, when do we start a new line?

choices.answer: When we have a new speaker in a conversation.
When we feel like it.
After every full stop.
Never

questions.question: How many days of vacation do you have left.

choices.answer: Correctly punctuated
Incorrectly punctuated

questions.question: How many missing pieces of punctuation in this sentence?: he cried its not over
